Introduction

Enlightenment rationalism may be said to have been birthed with the writings of Francis Bacon and René Descartes, and to have come to self-awareness in the works of the French philosophes (e.g., Voltaire, Diderot, Condorcet, and d'Alembert), and their allies, such as Benjamin Franklin, Immanuel Kant, and Thomas Paine. But almost contemporaneously with the birth of this movement, it attracted critics.

The aim of this project is to provide an overview of some of the most important of the many critics of Enlightenment rationalism. The essays on each thinker are intended not merely to offer a commentary on that thinker, but also to place him or her in the context of this larger stream of anti-rationalist thought. So, while this volume is not a history of anti-rationalist thought, it may contain the intimations of such a history.

Blaise Pascal (1623-1662): French mathematician and philosopher from the Auvergne region in France. One of the two pioneers of the mechanical calculator.

Jonathan Swift (1667-1745): Anglo Irish political essayist, satirist, and clergyman from Dublin, most known for Gulliver’s Travels and A Modest Proposal.

Giambattista Vico (1668-1774): b. June 23rd in Naples, trained in jurisprudence and student of philosophy, philology, and the classics. Author of Scienza Nuova.

George Eliot (Mary Ann Evans) (1819-1880): Known by her pen name, an English novelist, poet, and translator who wrote seven novels, including Middlemarch, which are known for their realism and psychological insight.

Fyodor Dostoevsky (1821-1881): A Russian novelist from Moscow, who was at one time imprisoned by the Tsar for discussing banned books. Dostoevsky is known for psychological novels such as Crime and Punishment and The Idiot.

Lewis Carroll (Charles Lutwidge Dodgson) (1832-1898): Anglican author and scholar who is known for his novels Alice in Wonderland and Through the Looking Glass, poetry, and works on mathematics and formal logic.

Max Weber (1864-1920): German sociologist, philosopher and economic theorist known for The Protestant Ethic and the Spirit of Capitalism. Died of the Spanish Flu.

Irving Babbitt (1865-1933): American academic, known for his founding role in the New Humanist movement, and as a critic of Naturalism and Romanticism.

Mikhail Bulgogov (1891-1940): A playwright, doctor, and author from Kiev, then part of the Russian empire. His plays and other writings are known for being banned and/or critical of Soviet culture. The Master and the Margarita, his most famous work, was not published until 1966.

Carl Schmitt (1888-1985): A German political theorist and prominent member of the Nazi party, whose political theories have influenced the neoconservative movement and Chinese president Xi Jinping.

J.R.R. Tolkien (1892-1973): Prominent fantasy author, writer of The Hobbit and The Lord of the Rings, fellow and professor of Anglo-Saxon at Pembroke college, Oxford. Devout Catholic and veteran of WWI and WWII.

Karl Löwith (1897-1973): A German philosopher and author of From Hegel to Nietsche, and a refugee from the Third Reich.

Owen Barfield (1898-1997): British philosopher, a prominent member of the Inklings, a British fantasy writers’ group. Concerned with the evolution of consciousness, he was founding father of the field of Anthroposophy.

Gregory Bateson (1904-1980): An English ecological anthropologist, cyberneticist, and social scientist. A systems thinker, he is the author of Steps to an Ecology of Mind.

Raymond Aron (1905-1983): French philosopher and political theorist who The Opium of the Intellectuals, in contrast to Marx’s statement “religion is the opiate of the masses”. Born in Paris, Aron was a rational humanist.

Robert Nisbit (1913-1996): American sociologist, UC Berkeley professor. A conservative, he was an advocate of traditional forms of community.

Stuart Hampshire (1914-2004): An English philosopher and antirationalist thinker who taught at University of London and was an Oxford Fellow.

Walker Percy (1916-1990): A novelist from Birmingham, Alabama. A devout Catholic, he wrote philosophical novels set in the American South, such as The Moviegoer.

A.C. Graham (1919-1991): A Welsh scholar and sinologist, professor of classical Chinese at the School of African and Oriental studies at the University of London.

Elisabeth Anscombe (G.E.M. Anscombe) (1919-2001): Irish philosopher and analytical Thomist. A student of, and later authority on, Wittgenstein, known for her monograph Intention.

Bernard Williams (1929-2003): Born in Essex, England, a philosopher and prominent thinker in Kantianism and interpreter of other philosophers such as Descartes and Plato.

James C Scott (b. 1936): An American political scientist, anthropologist and anarchist thinker who often contrasts state-based and non-state societies in his work.

Roger Scruton (27 February 1944- 12 January 2020): A conservative political theorist from Buslingthorpe, England. Lecturer at Birkbeck college.

John Gray (b. 1948): Analytic and political philosopher at the London School of Economics, who argues that human nature is inherently destructive and an obstacle to ethical progress. He is a critic of neoliberalism.
